title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining the US's position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. Research and development in science and technology contribute significantly to the economic growth of the country. Basic research explores the universe while applied research addresses practical problems. The United States emphasizes the importance of research and development in science and technology to promote economic growth. Education is crucial in developing intellectual capital for innovation. The country needs scientists, engineers, technologically proficient workers, and scientifically literate individuals to drive progress. The United States emphasizes research and development for economic growth, requiring technologically proficient workers and scientifically literate individuals. Student performance in math and science shows shortcomings in education, necessitating new teaching methods, curricula, and teacher training. Science is a process of inquiry beyond facts and theories. Improved teaching methods and curricula, along with better teacher training and parental involvement, are essential for enhancing education in mathematics and science. Science is a process of inquiry based on observations and data, leading to a deeper understanding of the universe through concepts and theories. Students should learn science by actively engaging in experiments and hands-on activities. It is crucial to start science education at an early age and maintain it throughout the school years. High-quality teachers play a vital role in connecting students with the content they are learning. Teachers are crucial for connecting students with the content they are learning in science. High-quality, well-trained teachers need to be recruited and retained with incentives for improvement. Training teachers in their content area, curriculum, and up-to-date research is essential for superior results. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by certain teachers. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a credit for qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers. The credit is 10% of the tuition amount, capped at $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive up to $1,500. The credit is available for the first 10 taxable years of teaching. Eligibility criteria are defined for teachers in elementary or secondary schools receiving funds under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers. The credit is 10% of the tuition amount, capped at $1,000 per year, or up to $1,500 for teachers in high-needs school districts. The credit is available for the first 10 taxable years of teaching. Eligibility criteria are defined for teachers in grades kindergarten through 12th who primarily teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers who teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades kindergarten through 12. Teachers must have a relevant degree and be highly qualified. School administrative functions related to these courses are also eligible for the credit. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a credit for qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers who teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades K-12. School administrative functions related to these courses are also eligible for the credit. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of the new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date. Only eligible teachers after this date will be considered for certain tax benefits. Additionally, a new section is added to provide credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. Regulations will be prescribed to implement this new section. The new section provides a tax credit for qualified STEM contributions, including STEM school contributions, teacher externship expenses, and teacher training expenses. Qualified STEM contributions consist of STEM property and service contributions. STEM property contributions would be deductible under charitable contribution rules if not for certain limitations. The term 'STEM property contributions' refers to the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the US for educational purposes related to grades K-12. The property must be used by the donee, fit into their education plan, not be exchanged for money or other property, and have its original use begin with the donee. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to the amount paid for STEM services provided in the US or defense dependents' education system for the benefit of students at elementary or secondary schools. The deduction amount is determined as if the limitation under section 170(e)(3)(B) applied to all STEM inventory property. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to the amount paid for STEM services provided in the US or defense dependents' education system for the benefit of students at elementary or secondary schools. STEM inventory property is defined as property needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. The term 'STEM services' refers to services needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. STEM teacher externship expenses are amounts paid for carrying out STEM-related activities. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for a program where eligible STEM teachers receive training to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to amounts paid for eligible STEM teachers to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics at K-12 educational organizations in the US or on US military bases. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to amounts paid for eligible teachers to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics at K-12 educational organizations in the US or on US military bases. Amendments to the tax code specify that no double benefit shall be allowed for any amount claimed as a credit for STEM teacher training expenses. Amendments to the tax code allow for a new STEM contributions credit for elementary and secondary education. The tax code amendments introduce a new STEM contributions credit for elementary and secondary education, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act ensures continued local control over educational institutions and school systems.
